150695617.review:
Kind of mixed for this one, but several rough design choices ruined it for me. The idea for the game itself is great and very unique being able to change the rules around you. My only problem though was pretty poor puzzle design I think. Most levels are unnecessarily tedious, they should have leaned more into the sandbox side of the game by allowing multiple solutions to levels. It’s difficult yeah, but it’s this tediousness that doesn’t make it fun to play. Puzzles are mostly trial and error and some brute forcing instead of aha moments. Levels are very confined and small, making you find one very specific solution to a problem only if you make all the correct moves. Literally nothing about the game is explained to you besides how to move and undo.
You gotta figure out just by accident that statements can be made downwards, the “Is” block can be used by two things at the same time, changing an object to something else makes it stay that way instead of reverting it once the statement is broken, etc.
It just feels very rigid all the time and if the dev had only taken the time to polish it and make it a fun experience all the way through then Baba Is You could be one of the best puzzle games out there.

Baba is You is a great game. Baba is You is a ruthlessly hard puzzle game where almost every puzzle seems impossible at some point. After the early game, there's always a point in every level where I feel like I've understood the situation and I think "Wow, so this level is just genuinely impossible." Then I end up having a eureka moment later and solving the puzzle.
 I bought Baba is You about 3 years ago, and it honestly changed my perspective on how I see problems and obstacles. Whenever I feel stuck, or incapable of accomplishing something, I think back to my time when I used to play Baba is You, and every obstacle that seemed impossible became possible. 
There's a level in Baba is You titled "Insulation" that I spent about 4 hours on across 4 days. I reopened the level the next day, and solved it within 2 minutes of having it open. The joy I felt wasn't a sudden rush of euphoria, but rather feeling of fulfillment and competence. I had been working on this level for so long, I was genuinely worried that I just wasn't smart or creative enough to come up with the solution. Then, I proved myself wrong again.
So yeah, I would recommend the game. You can play on controller, and you can pick it up at any time. It's a great game to just open for about 10 minutes and then close. Have fun.

149669702.review: Baba will twist your brain. Never felt this ecstatic after finishing a game level all on your own.

149640045.review: Pure logic puzzles. Forget the symbols and rules you're accustomed to in video games. You can open a door with a key, you can open a key with a flag, or you can melt a door with a rock. Your only objective is win, and your only limits are written right in front of you. Mind bending, but you will feel like a genius. Charming visuals and satisfying audio are a love letter to retro games. Hard but fair difficulty, although yes, you rarely use the same strategy twice in a row. What worked in one level is likely to be a red herring in the next. But there is no time limit, and you can take turns and undo them at your own pace, so the difficulty is satisfying, not artificial. Honestly, if you liked Zoombinis as a kid? This is that but for bigger brains.

149062917.review:
I was really surprised how strongly I ended up disliking this game. I don't think anything I played this year was a more deeply unpleasant experience. Back when I first heard of the concept of this game, I immediately fell in love – and sure enough, I had a lot of fun in the first couple of levels. I got stuck fairly quick during my first session – probably didn't even make it past the first world. I was pretty busy at the time and chalked it up to not having the peace of mind for something like this. I made it a bit further some days later, to about 20 percent or so of the game. And already I didn't enjoy that very much. However, I still liked the idea of the game so much that I kept thinking it must be me and decided to backlog it for now.

A few weeks ago I started the game up again. I had read some opinions/tips in the meantime. It's meant to be slow, you have to give it more time, think outside the box – the usual. I also repeated some of the earlier levels to make sure I wasn't getting stuck from having forgotten the lessons that were taught there. As I understand now, that was a mostly moot exercise. After completing the game I can confidently say that I will [i]never[/i] have the peace of mind for a game like this. It is incompatible with what I like about video games.

While I do enjoy hard games quite a bit and have no problem at all retrying a level in, e.g. [i]Celeste[/i] or [i]N++[/i], for hundreds (in some cases actually thousands) of times, I need to feel [b]progress[/b]. For example by getting better with experience, i.e. starting to understand how to approach a difficult level after some attempts and then getting farther and farther with actually implementing that solution in further attempts. Or more obviously via leveling up stats from in-game XP. Or in some other way. Baba does not give me any of that. There is no progress. You either finish a level or you don't, there's no in-between. This results in just feeling stuck for most of the time. The game has no difficulty curve, it's just a wall.

It took me quite some time to figure out what I dislike so much about this game, and this lack of tangible progress is definitely at the core. But I'd also say that [i]Baba is You[/i] ultimately is very misleading – the core idea suggests that you can be creative, and change the rules. But you actually – for the most part – cannot do that. Quite the opposite, the solutions to most puzzles are extremely narrow and you have absolutely no chance of beating a level if you can't figure out this one specific way of doing things. In addition to the lack of progress in this process (having solved the five levels before doesn't help you in figuring out the solution to the current level) the game is also intentionally obtuse: By constantly switching around the fundamentals (in one level, water is not passable, in another level water is fine but grass is impassable) you don't get used to anything and basically have to start from scratch all the time. There isn't really a point to that, because it doesn't change how the puzzles themselves work. It's as if Sudoku each time used a different set of nine unique symbols, so you never get used to playing with the numbers 1 to 9 – it doesn't change how to solve it, but it prevents your brain from anchoring with something consistent.
Even all that aside, sometimes the solutions are just ridiculously convoluted. I gave every single level a fair shot myself, even sleeping on it sometimes. But as time went on so did my patience, and I looked up quite a lot of hints and sometimes even full solutions. There's a couple of solutions where even after seeing and implementing them I still don't think they make sense or are consistent with the game at large, and rather just exist as one-trick-ponies to create some of the more "mind-blown I can't believe the game allows you to do this" moments. Another thing that felt really inconsistent was that even deep into the endgame, there would still often be levels that were really (comparatively) easy – because the level design mentioned above simply makes it impossible to arrange levels by difficulty in a meaningful way.

It pains me to give the thumbs down here, because while I personally almost hate it (and think it has some objective flaws) I definitely want more games like it in the world: Doing something different and wacky. It has overwhelmingly positive reviews so a lot of people clearly have gotten something out of it – and I know how amazing it is when a game does that for you. The game is undeniably a labor of love, but if your taste in games and puzzles is similar to mine you should stay far away from this.

Furthermore if you really love the mechanics and want more content there's a huge community of level creators which infinitely expands the potential content you can experience

146722573.review:
A challenging puzzle game in which you create and break rules by pushing around the words making them up.

[hr][/hr]
The basic gameplay of Baba Is You revolves around you moving around in grid-based 2D levels and pushing around different objects. However, each level also contains words which can be similarly pushed around. When arranged in the correct way, these words will form rules, i.e., causing specified objects to move, block other objects from passing through them, act as the player character or interact with certain other objects in different ways.

Using this system, levels are set up by placing their rules within them and require you to break and/or change some of them in order to get to a winning state. What exactly constitutes this winning state can vary depending on the rules, though you most often have to touch a specific object with your own character. The gameplay is somewhat hard to define here, as the rule-system coupled with a pretty big number of words that can be used in them means the things you have to do in each level vary widely.

Baba Is You has an overworld, divided into different sub-worlds. Each of these has a unique graphical theme and introduces a couple new words, centring its levels around their mechanics. Completing levels will unlock adjacent ones and allow you to progress further in the overworld once a set number of levels have been cleared.

While the early levels are quite easy to figure out and are mostly concerned with showcasing the possibilities the rule system provides, the game’s difficulty quickly picks up. Later levels take a while to even figure out, require a lot of out of the box thinking. The last world(s) step this up even further, taking the concept of what rules can do about as far as possible, which certainly left an impression on me.

In addition to the large main world, the game also includes additional level packs, introducing new mechanics and showcasing in-development levels within them. I found these to be a bit less cohesive and interesting than the main game, but they certainly provided a fresh experience with more of the established gameplay. There’s also an included level editor, coming with the ability to play other players custom levels created within it. Given this, there’s more than enough content in the game to keep you busy.

[hr][/hr]
Baba Is You is a unique concept executed wonderfully and has a huge amount of varied content. However, be aware that it also quickly becomes quite challenging, meaning most of the game will require great puzzle solving skills.

146193666.review:
Baba is You is definitely the best puzzle game I've played. It takes a basic concept and turns it on its head, and forces you to think outside of the box, or like the box. The only obstacle in this is yourself and your inability sometimes to think about other solutions. You may know how a level is won, but are too focused on a way to do it you can't think of anything else, so an effective way to solve some of these are just looking away from it and thinking about it again.

But I would lie if I said I didn't use any hints at all. Some of the levels seemed impossible and there are great ways to get spoiler free hints as to not ruin the accomplishment. That's to say, this game is not easy, and even without testing some of the player made maps you'll find it challenging. The difficulty ramps up gradually as you'd expect, and it does a great job introducing the new mechanics. Some of them are niche and reserved for only a few levels, but most of them are used throughout the whole game.

It's not a short game, either. They really made the most of it. There's more levels in this game than you can ever expect. And I mean that in a very literal sense. Each time you think you've beaten the game, you're proven wrong. None of the levels seem out out place either, but some of them are tougher than others when it feels like they shouldn't be. But generally speaking, you're going through them in a very logical order and your understanding of the game increases with each level completed.

If you're at all interested in the game, do get it. Even at full price I think it's more than worth it.

145601007.review:
Tras jugar y completar los niveles de todos los mundos principales de Baba is You, puedo afirmar que es un juegazo. Lleva los puzzles a otro nivel distinto con una mecánica muy simple: hacer frases para que se cumplan en el juego. Voy a hablar mucho, así que por si acaso quieres llegar fresco al juego, no leas a partir de aquí. Ahora sí, empecemos.

Baba is You es un juego que nos propone puzzles en los que nosotros cambiamos la forma de jugarlos. Puede sonar raro, pero vamos a poner ejemplos. Hay 3 tipos de bloques: los de objetos (como Baba o Rock), los "intermediarios" (Is, And...) y la acción (Push, Win). Alineando estos de diferentes maneras, conseguiremos que los objetos interactúen de esa manera. No sé como será el código del juego, pero tiene una cantidad absurda de interacciones. Todo puede ser o hacer de todo. Al principio es simple, disponiendo de pocos bloques, pero al final, se vuelve en un quebradero de cabeza, pero lo hace tan bien que es difícil criticarlo. Pero esa abrumación es precisamente lo que más quita al juego. Al haber tantas interacciones, el juego solo te enseña unas pocas, por lo que la solución a muchos puzzles se siente extraña y frustrante por lo poco intuitiva que es.

Todo en los puzzles está pensado. La mayoría de niveles tienen bloques que no pueden ser intercambiados, por si acaso se nos ocurre cambiar las condiciones que hacen difícil al puzzle, por lo que la dificultad aumenta muchísimo, pero sin sentirse forzado. Esto sumado al diseño de nivel de cada puzzle, que se amolda perfectamente a todas las características anteriormente mencionadas.

Audiovisualmente, es simple pero funcional. El estilo artístico es uno muy simple y la OST no es nada destacable. No está mal, pero es bastante simple, por lo que no rinde homenaje a la jugabilidad que es más dura a veces que una roca hecha de Nokias.

Como la historia es como un coche volador (todos queremos, pero no existe), Baba is You es un juegazo que si te gustan los juegos de puzzles debes jugar. Para jugarlo necesitarás ser muy resolutivo con poco, pero no veas lo bien que sienta completar sus acertijos. Recomendadísimo.

145299601.review:
(game gifted by a friend).

I think baba is you is a very good game. It's one of the types of puzzle games that I think are very deliberate, which doesn't always translate to "good" but does show a lot of planning behind the scenes. There are some surprising, and in my opinion very funny, hidden "easter eggs" (they are technically part of the main game but are miss-able if you're not experimental) that are interesting. The rules across all levels are consistent but do require experimentation to figure out.

I do think the game should have a little more handholding or an easily accessible way to test new knowledge (the level designer is very good for this, but runs into the issue that it's easy to spoil yourself for things you haven't encountered yet). But compared to some other popular puzzle games, I almost never get annoyed after solving a puzzle. (A good, uncontroversial counter example is old point-and-click adventures where you realize the solution was some stray pixel that you couldn't figure out without outside help or an immense amount of patience).

I think if the screenshots look appealing to you, it's worth getting. If you're on the fence, it might be worth getting on sale (usually 25-30% off during the major sale seasons).

144410640.review:
[I]Baba is You[/I] is a hard game. It starts off simple enough, but the difficulty ramps up somewhat quickly – though, with fairness. It’s also a long game, reportedly with over 200 puzzles in total. At the time of this review, I’ve only solved 51 puzzles (with help) and unlocked the first of two endings.

What I particularly enjoyed about [I]Baba is You[/I] is the hacker spirit it embodies. You solve each puzzle or level by manipulating the level’s rules, which are formed by tiles of nouns (e.g., “Baba”, “rock”, “wall”), operators (e.g., “is”, “and”, “not”) and properties (e.g., “move”, “push”, “win”). By moving and swapping these tiles, you can change the rules, and modify your environment, yourself and the conditions for winning. There are often multiple solutions to each puzzle, making the game highly replayable.

It was very satisfying to solve a puzzle on my own after taking the level apart so to speak, putting it back together with new rules, and making the environment work to my advantage. By the second sub-world, I started to need help. [I]Baba is You[/I] is not a casual brainteaser (well, for me anyway), and demands (pretty much) your full attention each time you play it.

Although [I]Baba is You[/I] is fun and delightfully challenging, I found it too long, too daunting, and in some ways too repetitive. Right now, I want a game that is quick to pick up and put down, and casual to play but not overly easy; one that can be played in short bursts and completed in several hours. [I]Baba is You[/I] [B]IS[/B] that type of puzzle game in the first couple of sub-worlds, but not once you’ve reached sub-world 3 (of 10).

So while I’m a not a genius and couldn’t breeze through this game in several hours, I still recognize it as a gem. Another way of looking at its long length, high difficulty and large number of puzzles is that you know this game is of great value even at regular price.

[I]Baba is You[/I] is one of those games that I’ll chip away at once in a while if I find myself in between games or bored with one. Probably the best puzzle game I ever played. 

I'm a big fan of sokoban games especially ones with interesting interactions such as Chip's Challenge. In Baba Is You, the rules of the game are the blocks you can push, resulting in some crazy puzzles. Not only is the idea really innovative and unique, but the sheer quantity and quality of puzzles is amazing. It is a very hard game, but it still has a pretty good learning curve as there are easier levels spread throughout to teach you how certain blocks work, and then further levels to get you to question that. Many advanced levels build on things you did to solve previous levels, so if you're ever stuck (and you will be), there are always plenty of other levels to play around with and think about.

I don't recommend using a solution guide for any puzzle game, but for Baba Is You, I REALLY don't recommend it. My mind was blown so many times while playing through and it is an incredibly satisfying experience. Just when you think you've seen it all, the game gets even deeper. For the best experience, do as much as you can without any outside help. I had to come back months later to recharge my brain and then when I started to make a certain amount of progress, I couldn't stop playing. In fact, I skipped dozens of levels and had to go back to them later because I just kept getting pulled further and further in a different direction :) If you're really stuck on a specific puzzle for hours and hours, there's a very helpful no-spoiler hint site that I recommend, but I only recommend it for specific puzzles that you're currently accessing. It orders the hints in terms of helpfulness too, so it helps to confirm if you're thinking about the level in a good way. Try to avoid hints on where to go next though, as doing so may sour the experience. Explore! 

Not only does the main game have a staggering amount of well-designed levels, but there are free official level packs that add new interactions, objects, and levels. There is also a level editor, and since the community is so huge and full of very clever puzzle designers, there is practically an endless amount of content. 

I'm writing this review before I'm truly done the game, but having experienced a good majority of it. Some puzzles are just so insanely hard to think about and I feel like I can keep coming back to this game whenever I need a puzzle, even after the main game. Hopefully the Scenic Pond will fall eventually :^)

Highly recommended!

142682180.review:
Alright, let's talk about Baba Is You—a game that flips the idea of rules on its head and challenges you to break them in order to win. It's a puzzle game by Arvi "Hempuli" Teikari where the rules are literally part of the game world, and you get to remix them to solve each stage.

The puzzles are set in small 2D spaces with various objects, characters, and words that define the rules. For example, you start with a white rabbit (Baba), a yellow flag, and some rocks between two walls. The rules written on the stage include "Baba Is You," "Flag Is Win," "Wall Is Stop," and "Rock Is Push."

Now, the cool part is that every word on the screen is a movable tile. So you can rearrange them to your advantage. For instance, you can push the "Win" tile to change "Rock Is Push" to "Rock Is Win," and now you can complete the puzzle by touching the rock.

Or, you can change "Wall Is Stop" to "Wall Is" by removing "Stop," allowing your bunny to walk through the walls. There's a bunch of creative ways to manipulate the rules to your benefit.

Baba Is You finds joy in the concept of rules, which might sound odd at first. But rules are the backbone of great games—they create predictability and help us master the game's mechanics. In Baba Is You, you not only see the rules but also get to modify them, prompting you to question your assumptions about how games should work.

I love how this game challenges me to think differently. Sometimes, when I'm stuck on a puzzle, I take a break, do something else, and suddenly, the solution clicks in my mind. It's like the game encourages me to reprogram my brain and look at rules in a whole new light.

With over 200 puzzles, I'm about 50 deep, and I can't wait to finish them all. Baba Is You is not only a fantastic game, but it's also inspiring me to rethink the rules in other games I love. It's a refreshing experience in a world where so many games demand constant attention.

142663408.review:
If you've taken a look at other reviews, you'll see this game is almost universally loved. And don't get me wrong, there are plenty of things to love about it. It takes a unique approach to puzzle games and with over 200 levels, even experts will find a challenge. Combine that with the fact that the rules are easy to learn, and you are encouraged to break them as soon as you learn them, and Baba Is You has all the markings of a fun, novel puzzle game. So why the thumbs-down? Because the novelty quickly wears off.

A lot of people, whether they love it or hate it, will talk about how the game is deceptively hard. Take a quick glance around the community hub and you'll see testaments of players spending days (literal days) on a single level. Whether or not this appeals to you is entirely subjective, but it is worth noting. 

My main issue is that Baba Is You is presented as a game where you can break all the rules, but it soon becomes apparent that you are breaking only the rules that the developer wants you to break. This doesn't lead to creative, unique solutions to the puzzles. It leads to one single solution for any given puzzle, a sequence so complex and restrictive that if you do not follow each step to the letter you will not beat the level.

What this means is that you don't have a game that capitalizes on some wild new concept, you have a game that plays like every other puzzle game on the market.

I think I would separate the puzzles in this game into two categories:

1. Conceptual
2. Precise

The former, thinking outside the box and asking "What are the rules? Can I break those rules? Can I make new rules to help me solve this?" are where the game shines. When you think to yourself "Will that work? Can I do that?" and then it does and you can, you feel smart.

The latter, where you understand conceptually how to solve the puzzle and must instead find the [i]exact[/i] orientation and position of objects in order to have everything line up perfectly, are tedious and time consuming.

Unfortunately, as the game progresses, it relies more and more on the latter. Puzzles with sometimes a dozen different parts where everything must be meticulously positioned and often have precisely one solution just got irritating and ultimately had me just looking up the step-by-step process that led to the outcome I had already identified 30 minutes prior. At some point I realized I was having less fun and getting no sense of satisfaction, even from the levels I completed myself, and simply stopped.

It is not a bad game, by any means, but most of its clever and unique ideas are found either in the beginning, or in the late game gated behind dozens of these tedious and finicky puzzles.

142456838.review:
[h1] BABA IS YOU / REVIEW IS WRITE[/h1]

As much as I hate some aspects of the game, I just can't bring myself to give it a negative review, as the things it does well are exceptional. I'm writing this review after beating every level available currently[spoiler]( 231 in total)[/spoiler]. I'll also say that I had to look up the solution to a few levels, because some levels didn't make sense to me even after knowing the solution, which I'll elaborate on later in the review.

WHAT IS BABA

Baba is You is a Sokoban* -like game where your goal is to rearrange words to satisfy or create a winning condition by establishing rules. 
The most common are : 
BABA IS YOU and FLAG IS WIN, meaning if Baba(you) occupies the same tile as Flag(win), the level is considered completed, but you could swap the words and make : 
FLAG IS YOU and BABA IS WIN meaning that your goal now is to reach Baba as Flag to win.
Throughout the game, you will encounter more words and more possible combinations to solve levels.

GAME IS PLAY

As already stated, the game is divided into singular levels and most of them can be solved in under a minute if the player knows the solution. The levels are accessed on a world map, represented by an island. You can move around the world map and travel to different zones, which serve as hubs*². The game does not require you to finish every level to advance to the next area. Upon entering a hub, you can always see the number of levels required to unlock a "key item". New zones are unlocked by just having a certain amount of "key items", so the player doesn't need to decide which area they want to unlock next.

THING IS GOOD

[list]
[*]One of my personal favorite things in the game is it's art style, as everything in the game is easy to identify and understand, with the added bonus of being able to run on almost any computer.
[*]Levels where new mechanics are introduced are easy and let you play around with the rules to give you a basic understanding of them.
[*]The "undo" button helps a lot, since it's easy to make a mistake in the game and not having to restart the entire level each time is great.
[*]Most levels are designed pretty well and sometimes give hints on how to solve them, without it being shoved in your face and looking unnatural.[/list]

THING IS BAD

[list]
[*]The difficulty of the game is insane in some cases; it ramps up from some levels so quickly, that you don't even have time to learn how to use a mechanic properly and the game already expects you to know every possible interaction.*³
[*]A few words have the issue of being hard to use or comprehend, as the introductory level only shows you a few possible interactions, which makes the easy introductory levels a double-edged sword.
[*]Some levels verge on trial and error, as some mechanics don't seem possible when you first encounter them.
There are some interactions in the game that look like the dev was just messing around in a sandbox trying to find the most obscure interactions possible and made them into a level without giving you the opportunity to see them in action.

[*]Now, my personal biggest problem with the game is the cumulation of the above to some extent:
You would think a game about breaking rules and remaking them would have a lot of freedom for making solutions, but it's the exact opposite; after a certain point in the game, you are restrained from doing the majority of interactions. 
If you somehow manage to find an unintended solution, chances are that the dev will just update the level to make that solution not possible anymore, meaning the game turns from "think outside the box" to "think inside the developer's box; otherwise, you're just exploiting the game's mechanics".
In my personal opinion, you should have the decency as a puzzle developer to admit when you have been outsmarted, but I guess changing the level to make your solution the only one is sort of meta in a twisted way.[/list]

THOUGHTS IS FINAL

As you see, I've written a lot more about the negative aspects of the game, but I still do recommend it, as it is a very unique game and despite all the issues with it, I still had a lot of fun with it, and the feeling of being a genius after solving a level is more than worth the frustration in some parts.

REVIEW IS END
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------


*  - Sokoban (eng. "warehouse keeper") from 1982 is also known as a "Box pushing" puzzle game where you have to push a box on a specific tile on the map. Many games since it's original release have implemented it as a mini-game; a lot of these games are of Japanese origin.

*²  - Hub refers to a zone that houses a set of levels with the same visual aesthetic and theme; these levels quite often introduce a new word or mechanic that is expanded upon throughout the entire zone and the rest of the game in some cases.

*³  - Queue all the people saying :"Maybe the game is too hard for you." or "You are just mad cuz bad", even though almost all of them didn't even finish the game or didn't even finish every level in most zones (according to Steam achievements at least), meaning they have no frame of reference of how hard the levels in this game can get.

141718502.review:
[b]TLDR[/b] The most ambitious and challenging grid-based puzzle game, it’s actually a miracle it’s so enjoyable. [20/20⭐, 60h🏅 (+40+??🏅 level packs), 5/5💡]

[b]Context[/b] Baba is You is a “sokoban-style” game where the player controls the properties of all objects in the map. This was not my first run at Baba Is You, I had already completed it back when it came out. But this one still feels special to me, a game so ambitious on its mechanics that it’s surprising it actually works - of course, mostly due to ingenious level design. And, the cherry on top, since I last played free level packs with new mechanics were released that effectively doubled the play time, as well as a level-sharing functionality making it potentially endless.

[b]Writing[/b] There is no actual plot in the game, just some thematically connected areas with different palettes. You can’t even say that (a) BABA is the main character, since by the very nature of the game, everything can (and will) be a playable character. Which doesn’t mean that you can’t feel for the little guy, as he looses its identity, is destroyed, pushed around, duplicated or transformed (it’s not as gory as I’ve made it sound really).

[b]Aesthetics[/b] The visuals are simplistic, but due to the huge collection of objects it allows for levels with interesting contexts. The wobble effect can get a bit annoying after long play sessions, but can be disabled. The soundtrack is also pretty cool and low key, but inevitably also gets tiring after hours of play (I can’t count the days I’ve spent with different tracks playing on repeat in my head).

[b]Gameplay[/b] To put it shortly, each level has a set of objects whose properties are determined by rules that can themselves manipulated in the level. To win, you have to move an object with property YOU (that you can control) into an object with the property WIN. Other objects are affected by a myriad of properties that can be either obstacles or solutions (e.g., STOP objects will block you, PUSH objects can be pushed, MOVE objects move on their own), and solving a level requires both manipulating the objects and the rules affecting them. Rules can also be combined with other rules and have conditions attached. And this applies both to the levels as well as to the world maps, with meta-consequences that I won’t spoil here.

If this sounds crazy, well, it is. Baba is You is the hardest grid-base game I’ve played, and probably the hardest purely deductive game (won’t compare with those with exploration elements as it’s a different kind of challenge). But it is also incredible fun and satisfying. As all great puzzle games, levels are usually small enough to just require a small eureka step, and not convoluted solutions. Even in the cases where you have to identify bizarre corner cases (such as the order of application of rules), the levels are simple enough that you quickly realize there’s something tricky you’re missing. But this is also a game that should not be rushed - at least I couldn’t. There were often times where I was stuck on all open levels and had to take a break (the game is rather non-linear with multiple worlds open at a time, exploring different mechanics). You can die and hit deadends in a level, but can always undo indefinitely or restart; progress is auto-saved, but the state of each level is not saved.

The New Adventures level pack is also amazing, featuring both worlds playing around with new weird properties which are pretty fun, and extremely challenging worlds that just build on already existing properties. The Museum level pack has variants of the levels from the main game and levels that were left out by the developer, and has director comments (which I didn’t find particularly interesting to be honest).

[b]Value[/b] I cannot stress enough the value of this game. On the second playthrough I still spent ~50 hours in the >250 levels of the main game (which was for sure higher on my first run); the >150 levels of New Adventures added further 40h of gameplay; I haven’t completed the Museum since I needed a rest from the game, but probably adds a dozen more. (This is without counting the hours spent daydreaming about possible solutions.) And I didn’t even explore the user-designed levels, since the game now features a level editor and a level sharing functionality. You can always revisit previous levels, and there are multiple progress slots. There are multiple endings depending on how far you progress in the game. Achievements are unlocked as you progress the game, and don't really add anything to the experience, and require a single playthrough.

141112449.review:
I have to recommend Baba Is You based off of its beautifully original concept alone.  That being said, this game is really, really hard, and I'm not sure if if falls in the Venn diagram overlap with "fair".  It just barely provides any help to you.  Normally, games are criticized for giving you too much assistance.  I criticize games when they give me too much assistance as well, but at least assistance normally doesn't result in me being straight-up bored.  I haven't beaten this game and probably never will unless I decide to look up the solutions on the internet.  This is because the game insists on you teaching yourself how to play while providing you barely any hints or direction outside of the level title.  I really just don't have the patience for this game to play it for extended periods of time.  Most of the gameplay is in your head as you brainstorm how to beat the level.  I frequently found myself not having fun while playing this, and if the game's not fun, why bother?

Notwithstanding all of that, I still have to recommend Baba Is You, as, like I said, the concept really is just great and perhaps I'm not the right kind of player for this unconventional genre.

140193622.review: I was intrigued at the first few levels of this game, since it has such an original and thought-provoking premise.  Soon though I grew frustrated and unhappy with my time working on the puzzles.  It took me awhile to figure out why, but I think it's kind of like this.  Imagine you're playing chess, but in the middle of the game, if you say put the queen next to a bishop, then the rules for rooks change so they move like a knight.  I mean one step like that is sort of fascinating, but if you make a puzzle that requires multiple such rule-shifts, then it begins to feel like an impossible job to look down the tree of possible solutions as it all becomes opaque quickly with each context change.  So unfortunately I can't recommend it, since it's core cool idea is also the one that makes it exceedingly arbitrary to play, almost like you just have to keep moving tokens around until you stumble upon the right setup that the developer designed for that particular puzzle.

Loving this game, the design is so simple and unique, while being very cutesy. This is definitely the best puzzle game I've ever played, even if I've put it down a few times and had to come back later. 
Playing it with my bf right now and we love it so much, the difficulty is definitely hard and my bf got his brain fried a few times but we've managed to beat the first 4 stages completely(all the extras). 
If we can do it, you can too. We're not overly smart thinkers, you just need to constantly understand that this is a game where you're supposed to think outside the box and use the mechanics in a way you never thought of before. Hypothesize, test, fail, repeat, until success. 
Anyone who complains that it's "too" hard are critiquing that a puzzle game is too puzzling. It's totally fine to take a break from a level and come back later with a fresh mind, that's sometimes the only way to make progress as it can feel like smashing your head against a brick wall otherwise. 

Only gripe I have about the game is that most levels in a stage we breeze through, only taking 5-8 minutes at most. But then we get to a couple where we can be stuck for a half hour to 2 hours. 
That said it's a great game and I can't wait to play it again, and eventually be among the 4% who have beaten the whole thing.

139654397.review:
Baba is You: A Hilariously Mind-Bending Wordy Adventure!"

Review:
Baba is You is a brain-twisting, word-flipping extravaganza that will leave you both scratching your head and laughing uncontrollably. This charming little gem is not your typical puzzle game; it's a wild chess game of words and levels, where you have to outsmart the game's rules to emerge victorious.

The premise of Baba is You is delightfully simple yet ingeniously executed. You control a cute little creature called Baba, but here's the catch: the rules that govern each level are written right there on the screen, and you have the power to manipulate them. Move the words around, change their order, and suddenly, you're altering the very fabric of the level itself. It's like playing chess with the English language, and the results are nothing short of mind-blowing.

Each puzzle in Baba is You is a cunningly crafted challenge that requires you to think outside the box, or rather, think inside the words. You'll encounter obstacles, hazards, and seemingly impossible situations, but fear not! With a bit of wit and wordplay, you'll uncover the solution that unlocks the path to victory. The satisfaction of figuring out these brain teasers is unmatched, and you'll find yourself grinning from ear to ear as you celebrate each triumph.

What truly sets Baba is You apart is the sheer brilliance of its craftsmanship. The game's developer has clearly poured their heart and soul into designing each level, meticulously crafting intricate puzzles that test your logical thinking and linguistic prowess. The way the words interact with each other and the environment is pure genius, creating an ever-evolving playground of possibilities. It's a testament to the power of game design when even the simple act of rearranging words can ignite a spark of creativity and discovery.

Prepare to lose track of time as you immerse yourself in the whimsical world of Baba is You. The charming pixel art, coupled with a delightful soundtrack, creates a warm and inviting atmosphere that draws you in and keeps you engaged. It's a game that encourages experimentation and rewards curiosity, making each "Aha!" moment all the more satisfying.

So, if you're ready to embark on a hilarious and brain-bending adventure, look no further than Baba is You. With its clever wordplay, challenging puzzles, and undeniable charm, it's a must-play for puzzle enthusiasts and wordsmiths alike. Just be warned: once you start, you won't be able to resist the magnetic pull of this quirky, one-of-a-kind experience. I would know as I have poured many hours into the Nintendo Switch version and bought this version because why not? I love the game and want to support the developers.

Rating: ⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐
Word Wizard Achievement Unlocked: Baba is You masterfully combines words and puzzles to create an unforgettable and ridiculously fun gaming experience.

139260468.review:
This is a sokoban game with a semantic twist.
As the trailer shows, the concept is an amazing new approach on the genre.
The starting levels are promising but the game stops being fun when "hacks" become the norm.

As far as I have played, there are 2 game logic rules which allow some things to float or overlap with each other.
Whenever there seems to be no solution, I remember these rules and brute-force and backtrack which things can overlap, so that I can get back to the sokoban, places switching and cloning parts.
Overlapping breaks how the game looks visually and it forces an unnatural 3d axis of puzzle solving which breaks the appeal.
People use float and noclip cheats to avoid gameplay in other games. Baba is you considers it a puzzle-solving feature.

Every level has a pretty much hard-coded solution. This would not be bad if you were not given the illusion you are in a solvable state. In sokobans, if you put a box against an edge, the game might still continue. If you place it in a corner and that was not the goal, you clearly can't play anymore. In Baba is you though, there are invisible impossible-to-solve states and the game does nothing to highlight them.
To make matters worse, the "undo or try again" message gives the illusion that it can detect a game-cannot-be-finished scenario. It only shows complete failure though. If you destroyed the only item which could have solved the puzzle or blocked it as part of your solution, you can spend the rest of eternity fiddling with the rest of the items.

I was going to grudgingly play the game to finish it just to see all the mechanics but I got to the wireless connection level. Up to this point there were some very limited options on how to chain the words to have an effect. There was the weird "Baba is Baba" short-circuit of logic that I could still accept. But in the wireless connection level, the middle part of the sentence is shown to be invalid in the working solution.
So to the developer of this game, should you read my review, I just want you to know that that that is is. This is not.

138043745.review:
By far the most innovative puzzle game I've ever played. Portal redefines movement and transportation of objects, Superliminal makes illusions come to life, and many other great puzzle games have incredible main mechanics. This one tops all of them. Easily.
This game uses its clever mechanic of text setting the in-game rules of the world and lets you interact with and rewrite the rules of the world. Baba doesn't have to be You. Rock can be Win. Flag can be Death. Skull can be Sink. There are zero conventional limits. The only things that can stop you are the map geometry and your own imagination.
You'll use this incredibly cool idea to solve some of the toughest puzzles I've ever seen, and progress through the heartwarming, fun, and strange world of Baba. Tons of fun to be had here with a game with theoretically infinite potential. 10/10.

137983695.review:
I'm not going to do the usual "BABA IS GOOD AND CLEVER" word arrangements to describe the game because everyone's probably already done that in all ways imaginable and I've already done it to some of my friends. But chances are my praise of the game will blend in with the woodwork too because of that "Overwhelmingly Positive" by the review count! Which is well-deserved, by the way.

The game is so simple to pick-up that the bare-bones trailer tells you everything about how it's played through a few simple movements and no descriptions whatsoever; how can I possibly beat that? If you've ever played FLUXX, the card game that's all about altering the rules and win conditions to your advantage, this game is kind of like that! You create simple phrases by pushing word blocks together which change your OR other objects' OR even the geography's appearance, traits, and movements on the fly to create pathways, traverse obstacles, and form other phrases, ultimately working your way to (or even creating if necessary) the goal.

It's so approachable and easy to jump into or out of at a moment's notice because it loads quickly, and while it can take you hours to figure out how to solve a single puzzle, once you figure out the solution, it can be done from start to finish in less than a minute. And if you make a mistake, you can undo as many movements as you like with the press of a button. And you will use it a lot, because rearranging phrases in ways that breaks your control or removes an essential object from the field is all part of the experimentation process.

It's a ton of fun priced just right. And don't be daunted by people saying "IT'S SO DIFFICULT" or the associated tag, I assure you the puzzles are clever and fair-- some just have an extra amount of cleverness to them. And my advice is if you're ever feeling like a puzzle requires an extensive, complex Rube Goldberg machine of words and objects all synergizing with precision timing and positioning to solve it, chances are you're overthinking it. But smart is Baba and Baba is you.

Baba is You is a masterfully crafted puzzle game that has won the hearts of players and critics alike. Its innovative gameplay mechanics, charming graphics, and engrossing levels make it a true gem in the gaming world.

One of the most striking aspects of Baba is You is its unique concept, which allows players to change the rules of the game by manipulating the words on the screen. This mechanic not only sets it apart from other puzzle games, but also makes it incredibly engaging and thought-provoking.

In addition to its innovative gameplay, Baba is You boasts a delightful aesthetic that is both whimsical and minimalist. The game's colorful, pixelated graphics add to its charm, while its tranquil soundtrack and sound effects create an immersive and relaxing atmosphere.

But what really sets Baba is You apart is its level design. Each puzzle is meticulously crafted to challenge players in new and creative ways, while still maintaining a sense of fairness and logic. It's a game that rewards experimentation and creative thinking, and the satisfaction of finally solving a particularly difficult puzzle is unparalleled.

Overall, Baba is You is a must-play for anyone who loves puzzle games. Its clever mechanics, charming aesthetic, and challenging levels make it an unforgettable experience that will leave you wanting more. It's a true testament to the power of game design, and a shining example of the creativity and ingenuity that can be found in the world of indie gaming.

137274413.review:
The term "genius" has been frequently used inflationarily to mean "really good" or "really smart". Yet I'd claim that Baba is You is genius in the non-inflationary, traditional sense of mind- and eye-opening, door-opening: showing us a new way to look at the concept of gaming. 
Baba Is You has exceptionally simplified graphics and sound. The main pull comes from the way that rules are at once utterly abstracted and entirely concrete. The rules of the game exist as tokens of written symbols which can be manipulated by simple movements. This means that this is a puzzle game that utilizes both logical and spatial manipulation simultaneously. 
The result is often devious, fiendish, and ingenious. 
A definite recommend.

136875836.review:
I’ll avoid the tantalizing low-hanging fruit of writing my thoughts for this game in its native syntax. Baba is You is the latest gift from the Finnish game development Gods housed in the frame of one man: Arvi Teikari. Just like previous eccentric auteurs before him - Lucas Pope and Victor Frankenstein, Teikari’s vision is uncompromising, innovative and brutal. Brutal not in the sense of a monster you’ve created murdering your fiancé but that the obstacles in the game and their levels of abstraction are tough. It goes without saying that despite Baba is You’s cute aesthetics, the puzzles become immensely complex as you progress. 

In order to lessen the mental burden upon the player, so one can avoid the fatal conclusion of “I ain’t playing that”, Teikari designed the entire game around working backwards from the solution. This easier-said-than-done concept is the the game itself, from the numerous ways one can tackle the very first puzzle to the meta-insanity of the final worlds. Perhaps the game should have been titled "Baba is Creative", though that does not pique interest nor is it fun to say out loud, but it is the principal theme of the game: there's as much freedom as one would expect from immersive sims. I could go on and on about how the design should be the poster child of the overused term “thinking outside the box”, but that’s not what matters. What matters is Baba is You is a unique experience unlike anything else in gaming, and it’s a great one at that.

135711674.review:
Baba is You is a puzzle game with a simple premise, which works out really well. Something that this game does really well is that puzzle solutions are generally very strongly connected with an idea or concept that you have to discover to solve the level. Some puzzle games have levels where you it feels like you have to stumble around trying a ton of stuff to solve a level, which feels pretty unsatisfying even when you do solve it. There are many levels in this game where I have to stop, take my hands off the keyboard, and think about the puzzle, or I might figure out the solution while taking a break from the game.
The developer also added in the ability to create and distribute custom levels, which makes the possible play time effectively infinite. Baba is You is definitely my favorite puzzle game: if you like the genre or are new to it, I think it's worth buying for sure. It's one of the few games that has a really new and unique thing to offer.

135387807.review: Baba Is You is a mobile app that's been dumped on Steam as if it was a real PC game (it's not)... it's a cash grab from greedy mobile devs.  The game is at face value a badly made 2D retro pixel ripoff of Sokoban, but it's much, much deeper than that as there's a few clever elements to each puzzle level that involve pushing things around to change the actual function of the gameplay and puzzle mechanics.  This is fairly clever, which strikes me as odd, because one would hope a clever developer would understand that PC gamers don't like mobile pixel trash very much, and would understand the basic minimum requirements games should satisfy to be accepted. [list][/list]From a technical perspective, as a mobile app, this doesn't meet basic minimum requirements that most PC gamers expect as standard.[list][/list]The artwork here is terrible, it's a blend of old retro pixel "art" used as a substitute for contemporary PC graphics, and some of the most amateurish MS-Paint style drawings I've ever seen.  It's unclear if this is due to lack of budget to arrange someone who can do graphics properly, or lack of talent, regardless, the overall visual quality of the game is extremely low as a result of these decisions.[list][/list]There's no options to change the resolution for the mobile app or customise the graphics settings.  There's no way for gamers to ensure this mobile app is running at the native resolution of their displays... there's no guarantee this mobile app will look right on any PC as a result of this hamfisted design decision.  There's no way for gamers to try improve the low quality mobile phone graphics. [list][/list]Bewilderingly, the mobile app doesn't include proper audio controls, so you can't turn off the annoying background music, you'll need to alt+tab out and stop the music using the Windows sound mixer.  This is obviously not okay and it's unclear why the developers chose not to include this basic feature.[list][/list]The controls can't be customised, which will be an annoyance for many, but it can also render the mobile app unplayable for differently-abled gamers.[list][/list]Because this is a mobile app, it carries a number of deliberate design deficiencies.  Compromises were made to cater to the iPhones that the mobile app was designed for.  These are unfortunate handicaps and limitations that PC gamers shouldn't be forced to accept, but it's evident that PC was an afterthought for the iPhone developers who are to blame for this.  The mobile app is deficient as a result of these choices, and would have been so much better without the handicaps that designing games for mobile phones forces upon a game.  Once more, mobile devs have made gaming worse for everyone.  I didn't spend thousands on building a gaming rig just so I could pretend it's an iPhone.[list][/list]Some of the defects in the mobile app can be attributed to the choice of using the Clickteam Multimedia Fusion construction kit - the "No-Code" construction kit that "Anyone can make games with!!".  Including, you know, people who aren't game developers.  Which is a problem.  This is a very poor quality toolset sometimes used by amateur developers as it's free (so they don't have to pay for GameMaker Studio) and doesn't require advanced game development skills, but unfortunately has very limited capabilities (it's arguably worse than GameMaker Studio).  Just as you can't make a silk purse out of a sows ear, you can't make a great video game if you use a terrible engine.[list][/list]These technical defects push this mobile app below acceptable standards for any modern PC game.[list][/list]Once more we see greedy mobile devs trying to scam PC gamers. On Steam, this is an eyewatering $15 USD, on app stores, it's less than $7. Mobile devs must learn PC gamers are not here to be gouged, and can't be expected to pay MORE THAN TWICE AS MUCH for a cheap mobile app just because it's been lazily dumped on Steam.  For comparison, $15 USD would get you The Witcher III: Wild Hunt, Hollow Knight, or Subnautica.  The developer genuinely thinks this construction kit MS-Paint garbage is as good as The Witcher III, so pay up!  [list][/list]This is unacceptable disrespect for PC gamers.  Because this is a mobile app, is priced to insult and gouge PC gamers, and because of the other defects, it's impossible to recommend.  Just who do they think we are?

135218951.review:
TLDR: Baba is you is wonderful, but massively overstayed its welcome. 

[b][u]General Thoughts/Overview:[/u][/b]

Buckle up kids, it’s angry ranting time. 

It was at 2:30am, as I contained my frustration and silently screamed “Why won’t you just end?!” at my screen, five ‘secret maps’ deep into what I had assumed was the last hurrah, that I realised the simple truth in an old adage: You [i][b]CAN[/b][/i] have ‘too much of a good thing’. 

Baba Is You is a simple yet somehow adorable little tile shifting puzzle game, where the short sentences you form change the rules of the game. Make objects pushable, pullable, floating, moving, and more in your quest to complete the level, generally by getting to a flag. 

It’s quaint and enjoyable at first, frustrating and enraging second. On the overworld I completed about 50% of the levels by eye, 25% with hints, and 25% I needed a walkthrough. This diminished by around 15% per ‘secret map’ until I found myself fervently reading walkthroughs [i]just to find the next secret map[/i] all in my quest to just finish the damned game.

I [i]never[/i] felt like I finished the game. Part of that was the fact that by the end I was just following guides, and is entirely on me, but the main part of the issue for me was the lack of telegraphing that the game had ended… If I had discovered the flowers were collectable in ‘a way out’ before reading up on how to get my last achievement ‘finish the game’, and I’d seen those credits… I’d have stopped a good 10 hours earlier, barely needed a guide, and this review would most likely be positive… but I didn’t, and it isn’t. 

Baba Is You is a band on its 23rd encore, which has outlasted the set, the diehard fans are all that’s left, still screaming for more, the majority have gone home not wanting to miss the buses and trains, there’re some angry clean-up crews trying to get the band off stage because they’re already four hours behind schedule, and there’s a sound engineer that called his wife during the first encore to say he’d be home soon and is regretting his life choices. And then there are a couple of bored teens, sat near the back while their dad sits behind them, arms crossed as he makes them wait, “I paid for these tickets and you’ll damned well endure the entire show.” he says, every time they try to head home.  

I am both that dad and those kids, who will probably never listen to the band they were fans of again.  
Anyway, angry ranting aside, let’s take a look at the pros and cons. 

[b][u]Pros:[/u][/b]
[list][*] There is an absolute [i]sea[/i] of levels in Baba Is You. If you want a big ol’ helping, this game has you covered.
[*] The music is fitting and the art style pleasant. The ambience of the game is just delightful.
[*] The feeling of accomplishment when you crack a particularly hard level on your own is just unreal. This game knows how to crank up the frustration so that sweet, sweet victory is all the sweeter. 
[/list]

[b][u]Cons:[/u][/b]
[list][*] Many of the levels are extremely frustrating, with very specific paths to solving them. 
[*] Many mechanics are obtuse, with some being outright irritating to try and get a hold of.
[*] The difficulty curve of this game looks like my elevated fucking heart rate. It’s up and down so much you’d get neck ache if you tried to follow it. There is a very fine line between fun difficult and purposefully obtuse, and Baba Is You misses that line far more often than it hits. 
[/list]

[b][u]Suggested improvements:[/u][/b]
 [list][*] At each of the map sections, there needs to be a game over screen. An actual one, not one gated behind flowers or puzzles, a simple, ‘baba is you is complete’ Bam roll credits, give a total completion score so the diehard fans can dig for more secrets. This would break the game up in such a way that people could more easily walk away from it. I don’t care so much if it isn’t 100% completed, I just want to feel like it’s reached [i][b]some kind[/b][/i] of definitive end. Even after finally seeing the credits, I don’t feel it’s over because of the way the game is set up. 
[*] Some sort of internal hint system… possibly one that can only be used once per level for each area you have 100% completed, giving a snowball effect as you travel, and making things a little easier along the way, flatten out that curve, if you will. 
[*] There really shouldn’t be any “how the hell could [i]anyone[/i] have seen and figured this out?” moments in a game. That’s indicative of poor design, if you’re tying it to an actual ending. If it’s a secret set of levels outside of the main game? Sure. But not in the main game, these moments really need to be eliminated to give the experience as a whole a more polished and positive feel.  
[/list]


[b][u]Overall Recommendation:[/u][/b]

Baba is you is a great concept, a fun game, and an incredible challenge. 
It’s just taken too far. 

Once again it’s a very personal thing. I’m a person who over eats at an all you can eat buffet. “I paid for this and I’ll damn well eat till I can’t.” Is that the games fault? No. But it does mean I don’t want to recommend it. 
This game is not for completionists. It is not for people who want to feel smart. It is not for people who want stories or progression arcs. It is not for people who are easily frustrated. 

Baba is you is for hard core puzzle enthusiasts. 

For everyone else, Baba is you is good for a few hours. If you can just walk away from it when it’s gotten too much and not care too much about what feels like a half finished game, then you’ll also enjoy this. 
For me? It was about 20 hours too long. It overstayed its welcome. It didn’t end. It probably never will.

134277906.review:
(friend gave me a steam key for this for free, so, shout out to you, thanks!)

Baba is you ("BIY") is a nice puzzle game where the mechanic is split into two parts:
1) the meta mechanic - the mechanics that govern the entire game; and
2) the level mechanic - the mechanics that govern the level you're playing

Normally you wouldn't have such a split, but the base mechanic in Baba is You is that you can use the meta-mechanic to create level mechanics for the level you're playing which then create the rules for the level. 

Which is clever and fun....however, BIY not without its faults.

A puzzle game that respects the player will know that the player having 100% knowledge of the mechanics of the game WILL NOT make the puzzles any easier...IF they are designed creatively. Filament is a good example of this. The rules of each room must be deduced, but the mechanics are not hidden from the player, you know you can't cross the filament and you know it is always extruded when you move. 

Unfortunately, many games get lazy in this department and they choose to start hiding mechanics from the player in order to make the game "harder". It's obfuscation confused for challenge, and it's a chronic problem in many puzzle games. 

And it's a problem that BIY dips into its fair share of times by hiding particular mechanics and depending on one simply guessing at it to learn them (spoiler: [spoiler] like two SHIFT objects stacked will act as a move object ... why? and where was that at all telegraphed?? [/spoiler]).  

Add to that the inherently cheap Sokoban mechanic, which is another example of lazy puzzle making, and you have a combination that is mildly annoying at the initial levels, but begins to get exponentially fu/cking boring at the later levels to the point that I turn into Wheatley trying to brute force GLaDOS's password in Portal 2's intro instead of elegantly coming up with a solution.

Which is to say this is where BIY shifts from fun and interesting to a chore; and the deeper I got into the game the more I realized this subtle shift. When you then also consider the fact that there isn't an overall compelling story linking the 230ish levels in the game together....one becomes less and less compelled to continue the journey. 

Ultimately, the late game morphs from puzzler into a di/ck measuring contest worthy more of a subreddit run by linux users than a game; because, honestly, if the solution to more and more of the puzzles requires one to inelegantly imitate Marie Kondo moving blocks of text around rather than cleverly manipulating them, then it's just going to be an exercise in seeing who wants to brag the most about beating a level. 

And I just do not give that much of a fu/ck about doing so when the only payoff is to one-up some reddit neckbeard or Steam user with an UWU anime icon.

The only reason the game gets a "recommend" here is because Steam doesn't have a number scale, if it did this would be a 6/10.

134244469.review:
[b]A novel puzzle game that makes you think about how objects can interact and how language can influence the rules of the game. Some difficulty spikes may deter some, but Baba is You is perhaps the best puzzle game released in the last decade.[/b]

+ simple rules govern how puzzles are solved
+ a lot of content for your dollar
+ lots of brain-busters, but never felt unfair
+ great and subdued soundtrack and audio cues
- often only one set of moves to solve a puzzle
- some early levels may filter out many

[h1]Full Review[/h1]
Baba is You is a top-down puzzle game which allows you to play with the rules of the game to overcome obstacles. On every level are indicators that [i]something[/i] is [i]something[/i] and you can move parts of statements like this to change how things work.

For example, most levels will have "BABA IS YOU", but you can move the "YOU" to attach to a "WALL IS" to then take control of all walls in the level. As well, some objects might have a "IS WEAK" to denote that it will break when pushed against a hard object, or other attributes that govern the properties of that object, like game over on touch, if it melts when touching hot objects, and so on.

There's lots of permutations and modifiers to play with, and puzzles often have superfluous statements that only serve as misdirection. Chains of statements can also get quite long as the game progresses, and the brunt of the challenge is figuring out (sometimes at a glance before making your first move) what modifiers need to be set to what objects in order to succeed.

There's several worlds, each with up to a dozen or more levels in each, and each level can take anywhere from a few seconds to potentially hours. The game is tough, and it becomes tough quite early. Even some of the first world's levels had me stumped for ten to twenty minutes before it clicks.

Baba is You is great, mostly because it's so simple yet intricate. Levels can sometimes not be obvious and even sometimes you can come up with a novel solution outside what the game expects. The game itself is also very novel, maybe other games have gone in a similar direction in the past but it's done extremely well here. It's super refined and easy to pick up, just how a puzzle game should be.

[h1]Steam Deck Specific[/h1]
There's no real graphics settings to tinker with. Game runs at 60fps even as low as 3w. The Deck's internal battery measure alleges up to six hours of battery and I can believe it. You can force levels to zoom in if there's room (some levels might not take up the whole screen otherwise) which helps with the small screen. This is the perfect game for the Deck.

Nowhere does the game even give you a hint that running into grass is going to turn you into a box only if you run through grass. 

I'm sure if the game taught you how all the mechanics work, I would enjoy it. But they just throw you into these puzzles and I guess encourage you to run around aimlessly after trying every combination. Even earlier stages were really confusing that I also had to look up hints after being stuck for a long time but they all kind of made sense even if I never saw them. This one where grass can turn you into a box had me scratching my head on how the solution even works. At that point, I'm just done with the game.

131669818.review:
Difficulty : 5/5 (Nightmare)
Global : 5/5 (Perfect)

Curator page : [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/44695991-Anokturnus/]Anokturnus[/url]

Baba Is You is an original masterpiece of creativity and puzzle design.

The goal is simple : you control something that is you (usually Baba) and you have to reach something that is win (usually a flag). Indeed, the form you and the winning element have depends on the rules written in the level. Each word is a block you can push and they form rules based on how they are organized.
The fact that changing the rules themselves is the main mechanic of this game leads to a very wide variety of puzzles, the dev was clearly inspired and fully used the potential of his game.

So yes the goal is simple but finding the solutions is absolutely not. The game starts like any game, with easy levels acting as tutorials to show you how the game works. But the difficulty quickly increases, and by a lot. Baba is the second hardest puzzle game I've played, it has a lot of nightmarish levels and becomes extremely hard halfway through. I really doubt many people reached the true end (and even fewer without hints).

A must, easily at the top of puzzle games.

131618823.review:
A charming, minimalist puzzle game that has a straightforward premise, yet has amazing (and very difficult) levels.

You are given all the rules in the level, and your goal is to alter them to make the level doable. There is nothing hidden from sight - all the information you need to solve the level is directly presented to you. It's very much a case of show and not tell: the game teaches you how different rules interact with each other by using them in puzzles. There are often several ways to do a level, none of them better or worse than others.

The level design is great, starting with relatively straightforward puzzles introducing basic interactions, and slowly ramping up towards the end, having some absolutely fiendish puzzles towards the end. Despite the insane difficulty towards the end, it rarely felt unfairly difficult. The answers were always there to be figured out, and with enough creativity and trying things out, they were always doable. It was rare for the solution to be a stretch.

The amount of content is staggering too, especially for the price. Even in the base game, there are enough puzzles to last 50+ hours, and that's before considering workshop level packs, which includes an official levelpack introducing many more blocks and almost as many levels as the base game.

Overall, one of the best puzzle games ever made. Would highly recommend.

130773737.review:
I think I hate Baba is You. Or, I love Baba is You but I hate what it asks of me. Or maybe I adore Baba is You but with the major asterisk that I used Baba is Hint from time to time because some times the things Baba is You asks you to come up with on the spot are fucking asinine, and require such liberal guesstimate reads of the fundamental mechanics that extend well beyond the rules presented that you genuinely will sometimes just accidentally guess the right answer after three straight hours on the same puzzle then have to reverse engineer how the solution you got even makes sense.

Baba is You is a game *about* love, I think. You move around in this four by four grid with this cute little critter named Baba, and you push around blocks that manipulate the rules Baba works by. You are a kid playing with metaconceptual Legos, and as you play you discover, and as you discover you learn, and as you learn you explore, and as you explore you find new ways to play. There's a zen here, I think, don't quote me on this I don't know zen philosophy at all, in the quiet meditative peace of just seeing what the game will allow you to do, trying different solutions. 

If there's an "optimal" way to play Baba is You, which i think there isn't as a facet of its nature, it's in finding new and better ways to fail faster and harder. How can you try different ideas without restarting a level, how many different ideas can you throw at a solution, how do you act when nothing you're trying is working. Maybe the most frustrating part of baba is you is how little it judges. You won't get feedback on whether your idea is right or asinine, whether your play is open or restrictive, whether you've even *beaten the game or not*. But I think there's something beautiful in that too- I finished Baba is You but it's more accurate to say I walked away from Baba is You, put it down like the bell rang for recess and it's time to go back to class and tomorrow I will pick up my toys and play with them again

Baba Is You feels like trying to write poetry in a foreign language. Box has love. Love is defeat.

It's perfect in its form, no more nor less than it needs to be. The mechanisms are stripped bare for all to see. They're simple, easy to understand. And yet there is so much depth to be drawn from just bumping words around, altering the rules, opening new possibilities, and, more often than not, completely dicking yourself over.

The puzzles are exquisitely crafted. Most will, at some point, seem impossible. As if they were created for a laugh. A joke aimed squarely at you. But keep trying, tinkering, and you'll get there eventually, the solution so simple once it's finally revealed itself.

A masochistic streak will help, sure, but if puzzles is love, buy is must. Baba Is You is an indie masterpiece.

BABA IS FUN. 

This is a game guaranteed to make you talk like a caveman as you excitedly work through the game's logic aloud to maneuver your way to, or make yourself become, the "win". The minimalist graphics mirror the simple rules you can manipulate, change, or push into a river, but deviously hide the intricacies of the challenges you must overcome.

A large part of the fun comes from experimentation with the rules, though they aren't always clear. Often times you will have to push the boundaries, search for rather unintuitive applications of what a certain condition or rule is capable of shortly after said idea is introduced. This results in sporadic difficulty spikes, though, as a puzzle game, your difficulty may vary.

Regardless, this is a satisfying puzzler.

129843445.review:
This game reminds me a lot of coding (and that's what it is in a nutshell). You're presented with a few codes (Baba is You, Rock is Push, etc) in the form of short sentences and it's your job to rearrange these codes to achieve your goal, which is to get Baba to the flag. Changing the codes changes the rules of the game. 

Rock is Push
becomes
Rock is Baba. 

Now Baba is a rock. (Not helpful, but that's an example.)

Gets more complicated as you go along where you can have longer codes/sentences (Rock is Key and Win) and makes you think harder for some than others. Some you think are supposed to be hard, but like in a math test, you're overthinking and the answer is simple. 

Great for people who like to code and/or do logic puzzles.

I don't think the game is bad at all, but it is way too hard for me, and for a lot of other people, I'd imagine. The novelty of being able to manipulate the rules of the game wears off when you realize that every puzzle has a single very specific solution. 129591781.review:
This game is, in my opinion, one of the best games released in the past decade. It will be looked upon as a classic game for years to come. I would recommend for those interested in the game to watch the two trailers, and then get through at least the tutorial section of the game (first 9 or so levels). If you like it after this, then you'll like the rest of the game. It is very consistent in how it adds new rules and tiles so it doesn't ever feel old. I would give it a 9/10 score!

Overview/Pros: As of writing this review, I have 90 hours on record. I'm not using a guide or looking up answers, and I've just reached the halfway point. This length will vary greatly from player to player based on their problem-solving techniques and if they use hints/look up answers. It is a very challenging game as it makes you consider several fundamental issues when solving a puzzle: 1) the tile pieces needed, 2) where the tiles are located (and how to access them), 3) the order of operations when adding or removing a rule, and 4) tile/item placement. Sometimes the solution to the level seems obvious, but getting to that end goal is not as clear as it seems. The game has 200+ levels, and they get progressively harder as new tiles and rules are added. The graphics are very simple and stylized, which is good in my opinion since it helps you focus on solving the puzzle. I think the music is nice and relaxing, although after hearing some tracks for 20 hours it can get a bit repetitive. I will be playing this game for many years as I try to achieve 100% completion, but for now I can say that this game is one of my favorites. Every couple months I'll try solving a handful of puzzles to progress. It is one of those games I think is best played in shorter bursts rather than longer play sessions.
 
Cons: Not all levels are created equal, as sometimes it seems like most puzzles are set up to be solved only one way in and in a specific order. You are granted a lot of freedom in some puzzles and not so much in others. This adds to variety, but I think it makes some puzzles more frustrating than enjoyable to solve. The rules are also sometimes hard to understand, such as EMPTY. I think sometimes if you are placing several tiles on top of each other it can be very confusing how they operate. At times it seems like puzzles can be too open ended to where you can't figure out what the solution or the starting moves are, which leads to confusion in what it wants you to solve. It can be a frustrating game at times, but I think it is also very satisfying to overcome the challenges the game asks of you. Of the roughly 120 puzzles I've beat so far, there have been only a handful that I spent 2 to 3 hours on solving. As I reach these later levels, I'm starting to take more time (sometimes reaching 30 minutes to 1 hour per puzzle). If you see time being a restraint for this game, I think this could cause some frustration for some players. With all my complaints I still can't fault it for what it is. The game does such a great job at what it does for me to hand-wave these complaints. At the same time I think these may be what makes or breaks the enjoyment of the game for others.
 
Overall I think its a very challenging, creative, innovative, and polished game! :)
