129456788.review:
[b] Baba is Lazy and Not Read: [/b] Baba is you is a phenomenally creative collection of brain-twisters, that leaves you both deeply anxious about your inability to solve puzzles that toddlers would find visually appealing and extremely euphoric when you finally solve them anyways (take that, toddlers!). Wholeheartedly recommended.

[b] Baba has Charm: [/b] The game is simple, visually appealing (might I say cute), with an equally simple premise. Baba is you is a sokoban-style tile based pushy puzzle game, where you aim to win isolated levels by... well, any means available. The unique twist is the game is that every rule of the game is quite literally spelled out as tiles. The sore reason you control the titular character is due to the titular rule being made in the game (clever, eh?). This means that fundamentally every level has an out-of-the-box, meta-ish solution, making for a very rewarding experience.

[b] Content is More [/b] The game initially has 10 worlds all with more than a dozen levels, plus the early tutorials and more difficult extras, all grouped around themes and novel game rules. The game also boasts 2 free level pack DLCs with new and exciting content, and also has a secret end-game that you access by [spoiler] a clever trick you should figure out on your own. Seriously, everyone always clicks spoiler tags anyways. [/spoiler] All in all, a vast amount of tough and unique puzzles to solve. The game also boasts a level editor and custom levels, which is a vast rabbit hole of extra content once you inevitably get addicted to the style of puzzles you find in the game.

[b] Review is Done [/b] In conclusion, the game is probably the bet puzzle game of the last 10 or so years, and is easily value for money. Game is Buy.

This is the best puzzle game (tied for #1 in my heart with Stephen's Sausage Roll). It has hundreds of puzzles, and they almost all challenge you in novel ways. The best puzzles require you to uncover interesting subtlety and surprising interactions via close observation, careful reasoning, and thoughtful experimentation.

I bought it on the Switch and completed it there, but after learning you could download level packs that others made, I had to get it on Steam, too. 128408358.review:
My brain is in a knot after a session of this game, but in a good way.

This game throws out all the familiar puzzle games tropes and let you define what is winning.
And if you said that this might seem like the game could have any win condition and the players would have multiple ways to solving almost any puzzle, you would be correct.

This is one of the most exciting and innovative games I have played in recent years and I fully endorse all this game has to offer, although I am of limited mental capacity and was not able to complete all of the levels, I did make it to only with about half a dozen puzzle unsolved and that's as far as I can go without watching youtube videos for the solutions. I can't say that the path to completing the puzzles I did was straight forward, as I have wracked my brain trying to figure out a few of the puzzles, and there were plenty of frustrating moments. However, every time you figure out a puzzle feels like a triumph and it consistently provides that through out. It has simple controls and mechanics, but they are all of them difficult to master and some of the mechanics take a while to get used to, but they are all individually simple and easy to understand. When you combine these mechanics, however, the game becomes infinitely complicated and the final puzzles in the game really test your understanding of the underlying mechanics.

The way this game forces the player's brain to twist and develop out-of-the-box thinking is something not a lot of games do. And even with knowing to think outside of the norms, the game's solutions might still delight/surprise you when you figure them out.

This is a consistently difficult and thoroughly enjoyable puzzle game. Everyone should give this game a go, even if you are not interested in puzzle games, because this is utterly unique and there is nothing else quite like it.

I genuinely love the game. I love the simplistic looking puzzles that can take a while of thinking, I love the atmosphere, I love everything about the game. 

Now, you may ask, why then I give it a negative review:

Spoliers ahead

[spoiler] The game lies to you. Several times. These are just the two most prominent I remember.
There are a handful of puzzles within the first two areas that straight up lie to you for later puzzles. One that comes to mind is a puzzle involving a conflicting block, something like an immutable "Flag Is Flag" in the upper left, and if you try and make Flag something else, it says you cant do that. OK, that makes sense. But it doesn't tell you that order matters, a puzzle or two later requires that you have that "Baba Is Baba" BEFORE you slide a block upwards that tells it "Baba Is Crab". I thought it would just break, or turn me into a Crab since I had slid the block in. Order matters. 
Fine, that can be intuited. I'll concede that. Maybe. 
It would've been nice to know at some point earlier "Hey Order Matters" without having to trial and error it.

Then Later on there is a puzzle involving a robot and the solution I could figure out broke the rule about conflicting strings. Or at the very least didn't tell you that a broken string [u][b] can still work with a broken part [/b][/u] 
ie. an immutable"Flag is Flag" then, the solution being to line up another string that reads "Flag Is Rock And Win". This will just exclude the "Rock" part from working and keep the rest. There's no tutorial for how operators work, and there's no way to learn some of the rules except by sheer dumb luck (or looking them up). I want to know the rules for the game, rather than having to figure them out through trial and error. I shouldn't be able to solve a puzzle because I'm a big dumb stupid thick idiot, not because I don't know all the rules. [/spoiler]

A 2D puzzle game seen from above where you push things around to form a path for you to progress.
Now, add the fact that the rules that define the game are themselves displayed in several blocks on the screen, blocks that you can push around to form new rules.

This is Baba is you.

In this game, this concept is used in incredibly effective and various ways. The level design is well made. First it start with simple rules and concepts easy to grasp. Baba is you, rock is push, wall is stop, flag is win. You are baba, you can pushes rocks, walls block you, the flag is your objective. Soon you are pushed to change rules and do things that can appear silly or bizare, like being a wall, walking on lava, pushing water, these little things you do not necessarily think to do.
I laughed when once, I spent 20 minutes on a level, when I found that in fact I COULD go through walls, because there wasn't any instruction 'wall is stop'. And yet I subconsciously thought that walls would block me
Then little by little, new mecanics are introduced in graspable ways, and the enigm complicates. Where the first levels will not require more than three minutes to win each, you will quickly find yourself breaking your head for half an hour (or many more) over a solution to win a single level in the more advanced parts of the game.
There's hundreds of levels, what's more you can create your own or the play the ones other makes (and god! People are amazing!)

This game is great if you have the patience to put effort into it. (and I understand that people will not necessarily have fun playing it.)

127432809.review:
¿Sabes esos juegos de puzzles agradecidos, que vas solventando poco a poco y que hacen que te sientas inteligente? Bien, pues Baba is You se sitúa en las antípodas. Su propuesta consiste básicamente en superar una cantidad nada desdeñable de niveles independientes entre sí, en los que normalmente el protagonista (Baba) ha de alcanzar un objeto que en principio es inaccesible, pero al que finalmente podrás llegar jugando y alterando las reglas que rigen en cada nivel.
Las primeras pantallas actúan como tutorial y resultan accesibles, pero la complejidad no tarda en aumentar hasta alcanzar cotas realmente elevadas. Esto se debe en buena medida al hecho de que al desafío que entraña jugar con la lógica y las reglas que rigen en cada pantalla, se une la necesidad de gestionar adecuadamente el espacio y la manipulación de los objetos y bloques diseminados por el escenario. 
Por este motivo, a la hora de enfrentarse a este Baba is You conviene armarse de paciencia y mentalizarse para sesiones de juego de cierto desgaste, en las que gran parte del tiempo transcurrirá frente a una pantalla estática ensayando y descartando soluciones. A ello hay que añadir un aspecto gráfico muy funcional pero poco atractivo y la ausencia de historia u otros incentivos narrativos para progresar en el juego, más allá de la satisfacción personal que sientas al superar ese puzzle que se te atravesó durante un par de tardes.
El resultado es un juego exigente, retorcido y arisco como él solo, pero que no puedo dejar de recomendar debido al talento que atesora. Pocas veces un acertijo te dejará indiferente y la mayor parte de las soluciones son realmente ingeniosas (algunas de ellas poseen un componente meta que te volará fácilmente la cabeza). Entiendo, eso sí, que no es para todo el mundo y recomiendo afrontarlo, como he indicado, con altas dosis de paciencia, en sesiones cortas e, incluso, con una buena guía cerca a la que recurrir ocasionalmente.

126532953.review:
This game has a very steep difficulty curve; there's a reason that the global achievement percentages are so low.

However, there's also a reason the positive review percentage is so high: the mechanics of the game feel fair, and the concept itself is genius. It's pretty obvious from the start that you'll have to think outside the box to advance,  and if you can remember that, you can make steady progress. I'm a puzzle away from completing a fourth area, and there is SO much more content left in the main world. That's not counting all the extra levels this game's got packed in, as well as the ability to make your own puzzles. 

This is easily the most impressive, nuanced, and original puzzle game I've ever played. It's hard to come up with a single con. Its storage size is tiny, its hardware requirements are virtually nothing, and its visuals are lightweight enough to draw focus to the puzzles without sacrificing a pleasant aesthetic. I would only ever advise you not to get this if you've done very poorly in other puzzle games, because Baba Is You is likely much more difficult. I think it would be fair to admit I probably wouldn't enjoy this if I felt completely stuck regularly, regardless of the game's immaculate quality. 

That being said, if you feel confident that you can at least make some progress, the first few areas of the game are a blast to play, and the deeper levels, while spiking in difficulty, are extremely satisfying to finally overcome. There's only a handful of other games that I have ever felt this positively about, so I highly recommend this.

It takes a while to complete the game, also it is mandatory that you would have to google solutions sometimes. Anyway the game is fun, forces to think out of the box sometimes. There are lots of secret level, even the same amount as "normal" levels, and I really love secrets in games since playing Quake 1 long time ago.
The only negative impression however is that the game is not 100% honest with you: there are some tricks to do that are neither obvious nor intuitive. Having this tricks known will help you to solve the most annoying and stressful levels. Here they are:
- you can and should stack text pieces whenever possible, this is achievable via:
  a) teleport
  b) shifts (e.g. belt effect)
  c) moving some item on a text and then converting this item to "text" (Item is Text)
- two stacked items with "shift" feature will make it self-propelled vehicle

Again, use the above tricks when possible and beat those unsolvable levels ;)

This game will destroy you and have you babbling incoherently in a language few understand. Easily the best puzzler I've played. Far too much depth for such a cheap game.

But be prepared for some frustrating hours spent feeling like an idiot until finally, you figure it out only for the next level to be very similar but your method no longer working due to a minor change in the level. Be prepared for the levels to get increasingly incomprehensible, and frankly, be prepared to not finish the game as it will get difficult enough to put down. 190 levels and counting and I'm still not done, but getting close.

Take time off to reset if you get stuck and you will get stuck. But the rewarding feeling is pretty fantastic when you do manage to solve it. 

If you like puzzles, get this game. If you don't want to spend hours and fail, nearly going crazy in the process, don't get this game. (and trust me, you'll spend a few hours on some of these puzzles only to not succeed and be on the verge of tears. I know I have been there, several times, including a year long break on one of the puzzles). 

This game will destroy you and if you emerge victorious, rebuild you.

121404115.review:
[h1]Baba Is Fun, Sintag Make Review[/h1]

Baba Is You is a puzzle game where you play as [b]Baba*[/b], a ewe who must reach a flag* to win the level.
[spoiler]*You're not always Baba, and it's not always a flag.[/spoiler]

Plot Is NOT Here.

Gameplay revolves around rules.  The game's rules are malleable, as in they're physical objects that you can shove around to alter rules, make new rules, break rules, add descriptors to rules, and more.  This is the central conceit of the game, and it executes it masterfully.  From the trailer, we can change Baba Is You to Rock Is You, and now you're a rock that has to go to a flag.  This is just the bare basics, and the game's exact wording, loopholes, unwritten rules that are active unless NOT, and the puzzles all of this makes, mean Baba Is You is a fiendish little puzzler.  I won't spoil any details here, but just know that it gets patently insane.  Thankfully, there's an 'undo' and 'reset' button on standby if you have irrevocably screwed up (usually by breaking 'Is You' with nothing to be You)

Graphics are pixellated goodness with a sort of 'wobble' to them, with playable characters having just two states of motion, similar to old Mega Man titles, with both states having said 'wobble' to them.  This is good.  They're simple, but the graphics lend a cutesy charm to the entire game that makes it adorable and innocent.

Performance-wise, you could probably run this on a Samsung fridge.  Moving on.

Multiplayer Is Empty.

[u]Baba Is You is well worth the asking price.[/u]  It's a difficult, but fun puzzle game that rewards lateral thinking with the rules in play, and it's charming as heck besides.  Even if you're like me and you absolutely suck at puzzle games, it's a simple, fun game that wants you to have a good time.

119795474.review:
In short, 'Baba Is You' is a game in which you are presented with many puzzles involving simple rules like "[BABA] [IS] [YOU]" which can be altered and moved around. In each puzzle, the goal is that the object "[YOU]" is on top of another object that is "[WIN]". At first, this may seem like it lacks a challenge. However, you will quickly learn that the addition of simple concepts as pushable objects (enforced by rules such as "[ROCK] [IS] [PUSH]") and impassable objects (e.g. "[WALL] [IS] [STOP]"), this win condition may prove to create interesting challenges to be solved.

The challenges often require a certain perspective on the puzzle which you may not recognize easily. So if you want to play this game, expect to be sometimes staring at a single screen for an hour (or maybe longer) for that final "Aha!"-moment you had been waiting for. [It should be mentioned that you don't necessarily need to stare at a single screen, it is just the way I played the game most often. There is definitely room for some trial and error (encouraged by the ability to undo moves), and you could of course also think of solutions when you are not directly looking at the puzzles.]

As a fan of puzzle games, I would gladly recommend this game to anyone with even the smallest amount of interest in puzzle games. The unique solving experiences with the almost endless amount of puzzles the game provides are definitely worth both my money and my time. However, note that this game is known to be very hard even though difficulty should be subjective. 

The ways to think about most of the puzzles are almost unlimited, so having completed the game myself I would recommend the use of some kind of hint system for yourself. However, you should really only ever use it if you really cannot figure out the solution after considering many angles to the puzzle and are desperate. I personally would recommend the one by 'keyofw' called 'Baba is Hint'; they don't give away the solution in any way, but guide you towards the right direction with intentionally vague hints. Also note that it generally helps to take breaks because they allow you to think of perspectives you did not consider before.

At last, I have one small point of personal critique for the game. To illustrate it I am going to make an analogy. One could do mathematics without directly knowing of the so-called axioms. However, in my opinion, to truly understand mathematics one should know of these axioms (almost) by heart. The game design is brilliant: generally you do not have the need of knowing the 'axioms' of the game, but they are there! For example, the rule "[TEXT] [IS] [PUSH]", while not visible, is present at all times, but you do not need to know of this because the game makes its presence apparent. Although I always was able to solve the puzzles without the presence of the 'axioms' in the end (sometimes with the use of some hints, mind you), I sometimes felt the need to know of them.

118055994.review:
This review does not contain a single 'X is Y' joke.

I've never been more upset that I'm too stupid to solve a game than with this one.
I knew I had something special in my hands as soon as I started roaming around the world-map and accidentally seemed to have solved a puzzle that sent me to a completely [i]different[/i] world map somehow, but man, some of the logic here is just far beyond my reckoning.  Having to figure out the order of specific things to do here is like trying to learn a programming language when you barely understand math.  This game has given me some of the biggest 'AHA!' moments of my entire life, but I found myself becoming stumped way too early in the game, and it wouldn't be much of a game at all if all I did was glue my eyes to a walkthrough and refused to work things out on my own.  So I'm personally stuck in something of a limbo with this game, not able to rise to the challenge of making Baba somehow push things around so they work correctly in my mind, but wanting to play it nonetheless.

Would I recommend this brain-scramble of an experience to anyone else?  Yes.  To every single person I've become friends with, actually.  Even if all it'd be for is just to watch them try to figure out how to turn a sheep into a brick wall so they can clone flying letters that need to destroy a flag to put the key in lava and win the level so Baba can take a dang bath.
I'd bet that's actually one of the level solutions.

For the record, I normally HATE brain-teaser puzzle games like this.  I'd never be able to play through something like Fez or The Talos Principle without going mad.  This one is just somehow... pleasant.  Like someone hitting you in the face with a foam noodle instead of a baseball bat.  Its out-of-the-box solutions are somehow perfectly logical, once you get a handle on this game ([i]not that doing so is particularly easy[/i]), and it just appeals to that secret-hunter in me who so badly wants to know what lays beyond the Baba-shaped veil.

's just good.  The devs knocked it outta the park with this one, and I'm excited to see what else they do.

I think this game has a clever concept, but I think the introduction of the new mechanics and pacing are not that good. New mechanics are introduced through tutorial puzzles, which can be a good way, but there are not enough tutorial puzzles. Many ways in which a new mechanic like switch or fall are used, are newly introduced through the more difficult puzzles, which resulted in me constantly opening a wiki to look up what something exactly means, because I didn't know what to do with it. There are also many instances where ways of interacting with a mechanic used last three worlds ago are then again used in a new difficult puzzle, so that by that time, I've already forgotten that a certain way of using a block or rule is possible. 

I see many people say that this game is difficult, and in general I can enjoy difficult games, but I find that for me too much of the difficulty comes from not remembering how certain things work and not being properly introduced to a mechanic and needing to look them up in a wiki. 

I will end on a positive note, because this game has many settings for how intense you want the visuals to be, plus some ways to customize audio, and as someone who gets easily visually and auditorily overstimulated, this is great in terms of accessibility.

Baba is You is a puzzle game that requires you to change the very rules of the game in order to win. The way this game requires you to think isn't like any other puzzle game, and it resembles the old days of Flash games. While the puzzles can get quite difficult, I never feel as though they're impossible for me to complete. The logic used to complete levels is similar to the logic used in coding, and despite the absurdity of it all, it somehow makes perfect sense. BABA is YOU is WIN.

Pros:
- Easy to pick up and put down, each puzzle is a single level
- Satisfying to mess with the rules of the game
- Relaxing to play thanks to the cute visuals and calm music

Cons:
- The game doesn't explain the rules to you - you'll have to test them out yourself (pro for some, con for others)
- You'll have to retrace your steps and reset a lot due to how the game works, this game takes more time than it looks

117287964.review:
[b]Sights & Sounds[/b]
- Cute pixel graphics
- Music will be stuck in your head for days. You'll hear it while you sleep

[b]Story & Vibes[/b]
- Rose is red
- Violet is blue
- Flag is win
- Baba is you

[b]Playability & Replayability[/b]
- Hundreds of soul-crushingly difficult puzzles
- I think 100%ing this game is for more persistent people than me. I can't figure out what I'm doing wrong to not unlock the "Not Baba" achievement. I got to the "meta" levels, but my achievement didn't pop. I poked around and tried to figure out what I was missing with a walkthrough, but no luck
- Not sure it's a game I'd replay, but I appreciate the challenge this game posed
- Remember: experimentation is your friend! You won't get far in this game unless you're willing to try a lot of different possibilities, even if it seems like they lead nowhere

[b]Overall Impressions[/b]
- It's the hardest game you'll ever play. You'll think about it when you're trying to sleep or when you're daydreaming
- This is definitely a game for people who chase those "eureka" moments; that rush of dopamine that floods your brain when the solution finally presents itself
- Definitely a fun game for programmers who enjoy finding abstract solutions through lateral thinking

[b]Final Thoughts[/b]
- [b]9/10[/b]. Smash your brain against this. There's no shame in using hints, but I'd really recommend at least beating the game on your own before resorting to a walkthrough. You'll miss out on the enjoyment of figuring it out yourself if you do

This is a game about feeling as stupid as possible. The first few levels are easy but then there are puzzles that any 12 year old could solve blindfolded 5 years ago and you question your entire existence.

It's also a game for people who would like to learn to code, but rather than really study it, would rather just play some game, waste their time and not feel guilty about it.

The game is good and challenging. I like it.

8/10
